narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I gained fundamental understandings of the history and basic beliefs and practices of Hinduism, Buddhism, Christianity, Islam, and some less popular religions related to each.  Rather than simply explain background details about each religion, Professor Bowering explained how each religion came to be through the people that practiced and lived it.
Learned about all of the major religions.
I learned a lot, not only about religions, but also the Humanities in general. When it comes to skills, I learned how to structure a paper in this topic.
I learned a plethora of lessons about the different world religions, how they spread, and their beliefs.

The course was filled with information packed lectures that gave a great look into the major religions in the world.  I learned details and history of the religions, and the connections between them.  We especially focuses on Hinduism, Buddhism, Judaism, Islam, and Christianity.
Overview of religions.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The material was delivered in a captivating manner, though lectures did at times feel long.  It would have been nice to break lecture up with the occasional discussion, though I'm sure that this is more easy to achieve in-person in a seminar or small lecture.
Interesting and great professor, hard to pay attention because a lack of structure

The strength is the professor and his willingness to help in any way possible, as well as the way in which he makes intricate religious concepts very easily understandable. The only weakness is that it could be approached in a more interactive way if there's a small number of students in the lecture.

This course was excellent. Professor Bowering led phenomenal lectures. He is really well-knowledgeable of the various religions. Furthermore, Nate was a fabulous Teaching Fellow that gave us essential notes that helped in understanding various topics. He also led one lecture that was amazing.

Strengths: The information was presented in a very organized way that facilitated learning and understanding.  Virtually, it can be a bit difficult to spell out terms without seeing them on a blackboard.  This problem was addressed by the TA who would send it to us in the chat.  
Weakness: It would be helpful to have a few minutes every now and then to ask questions to the professor, but the TA was helpful answering them in the chat.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The class adapted to the COVID-19 pandemic by having live lectures over Zoom that were recorded for asynchronous viewing.  Classes are generally less engaging when taught online, but this class succeeded online by not changing much other than shifting to online delivery.
The option for the synchronous or recorded lecture worked well.
The course was very well-taught and everyone did everything possible to facilitate learning during COVID-19.
The TA was very helpful using the chat top send notes and answering questions while the professor was lecturing.  The chat feature was a great help.
Good. The final paper is especially intriguing.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would likely recommend this course to another student if they were interested in the subject matter and had the opportunity to take it in-person.  I enjoyed learning the class material but felt like I missed out on the discussion opportunities that an in-person experience would be more suited to provide.
Yes! Great 5th class and super interesting with low workload
I would really recommend this course to anyone interested in the Humanities. You don't need to be familiar with religions to succeed, and the topics are incredibly interesting!
Yes, I certainly recommend this course to another student. Every student who takes this course will learn a variety of lessons and enjoy every moment of it.

Yes yes yes, but only if you're truly interested in learning about the different religions.  The professor gives a very in depth understanding and lectures are information heavy so if you're not interested from the start you will get bored quickly.  Overall I left with a really great understanding of religions all over the world and it was very enjoyable.
Yes, if you want to learn about religion.

Yes! It's a really great introduction to the traditions, history, and theology of some major world religions, and Professor Bowering is a really knowledgable and interesting person with great insights.
